/**
     * Constructor
     * Image can be initialized with any canvas drawable or a string.
     * The string should be a url and will be loaded as an image.
     * Canvas and Image element work out of the box, while videos require extra code to work.
     * Please check video element events for seeking.
     * @param {HTMLImageElement | HTMLCanvasElement | HTMLVideoElement | String} element Image element
     * @param {Object} [options] Options object
     * @param {function} [callback] callback function to call after eventual filters applied.
     * @return {fabric.Image} thisArg
     */
description:
Constructor
Image can be initialized with any canvas drawable or a string.
The string should be a url and will be loaded as an image.
Canvas and Image element work out of the box, while videos require extra code to work.
Please check video element events for seeking.

/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * This is the special image version where we would like to avoid caching where possible.
     * Essentially images do not benefit from caching. They may require caching, and in that
     * case we do it. Also caching an image usually ends in a loss of details.
     * A full performance audit should be done.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
This is the special image version where we would like to avoid caching where possible.
Essentially images do not benefit from caching. They may require caching, and in that
case we do it. Also caching an image usually ends in a loss of details.
A full performance audit should be done.
name: shouldCache

/** * IText class (introduced in v1.4) Events are also fired with "text:" * prefix when observing canvas. * @class fabric.IText * @extends fabric.Text * @mixes fabric.Observable * * @fires changed * @fires selection:changed * @fires editing:entered * @fires editing:exited * * @return {fabric.IText} thisArg * @see {@link fabric.IText#initialize} for constructor definition * *

Supported key combinations:

* 
   *   Move cursor:                    left, right, up, down
   *   Select character:               shift + left, shift + right
   *   Select text vertically:         shift + up, shift + down
   *   Move cursor by word:            alt + left, alt + right
   *   Select words:                   shift + alt + left, shift + alt + right
   *   Move cursor to line start/end:  cmd + left, cmd + right or home, end
   *   Select till start/end of line:  cmd + shift + left, cmd + shift + right or shift + home, shift + end
   *   Jump to start/end of text:      cmd + up, cmd + down
   *   Select till start/end of text:  cmd + shift + up, cmd + shift + down or shift + pgUp, shift + pgDown
   *   Delete character:               backspace
   *   Delete word:                    alt + backspace
   *   Delete line:                    cmd + backspace
   *   Forward delete:                 delete
   *   Copy text:                      ctrl/cmd + c
   *   Paste text:                     ctrl/cmd + v
   *   Cut text:                       ctrl/cmd + x
   *   Select entire text:             ctrl/cmd + a
   *   Quit editing                    tab or esc
   *
* *

Supported mouse/touch combination

* 
   *   Position cursor:                click/touch
   *   Create selection:               click/touch & drag
   *   Create selection:               click & shift + click
   *   Select word:                    double click
   *   Select line:                    triple click
   *
*/
description: IText class (introduced in v1.4) Events are also fired with "text:" prefix when observing canvas.
name: IText
see:
{@link fabric.IText#initialize} for constructor definition

Supported key combinations:

  Move cursor:                    left, right, up, down
  Select character:               shift + left, shift + right
  Select text vertically:         shift + up, shift + down
  Move cursor by word:            alt + left, alt + right
  Select words:                   shift + alt + left, shift + alt + right
  Move cursor to line start/end:  cmd + left, cmd + right or home, end
  Select till start/end of line:  cmd + shift + left, cmd + shift + right or shift + home, shift + end
  Jump to start/end of text:      cmd + up, cmd + down
  Select till start/end of text:  cmd + shift + up, cmd + shift + down or shift + pgUp, shift + pgDown
  Delete character:               backspace
  Delete word:                    alt + backspace
  Delete line:                    cmd + backspace
  Forward delete:                 delete
  Copy text:                      ctrl/cmd + c
  Paste text:                     ctrl/cmd + v
  Cut text:                       ctrl/cmd + x
  Select entire text:             ctrl/cmd + a
  Quit editing                    tab or esc

Supported mouse/touch combination

  Position cursor:                click/touch
  Create selection:               click/touch & drag
  Create selection:               click & shift + click
  Select word:                    double click
  Select line:                    triple click

and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
making bargain with performances.

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.
name: hasStroke

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a fill
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the fill is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
description:
return true if the object will draw a fill
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the fill is invisible.
name: hasFill

comment:
/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12
name: needsItsOwnCache

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
name: shouldCache

description:
Check if this object or a child object will cast a shadow
used by Group.shouldCache to know if child has a shadow recursively
name: willDrawShadow

/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
params.name: options

params.description: Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.left

params.description: Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.top

params.description: Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
params.name: options.enableRetinaScaling

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
params.name: options.withoutShadow

name: cloneAsImage

/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drawbacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     * @return {CanvasPattern} a pattern to use as fill/stroke style
     */
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drawbacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
this setting is performance and application dependant.

     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.

     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.

return true if the object will draw a stroke

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument

Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean

return true if the object will draw a stroke

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4

     * When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular
     * situation you may want this to be disabled ( spray brush, very big, groups)
     * or if your application does not allow you to modify properties for groups child you want
     * to disable it for groups.
     * default to false
     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: statefullCache
description:
When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular
situation you may want this to be disabled ( spray brush, very big, groups)
or if your application does not allow you to modify properties for groups child you want
to disable it for groups.
default to false
since 1.7.0

comment:
/**
     * When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
     * too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
     * this setting is performance and application dependant.
     * default to true
     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default true
     */
name: noScaleCache
description:
When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
this setting is performance and application dependant.
default to true
since 1.7.0

List of properties to consider when checking if cache needs refresh

/**
     * a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
     * the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center
     * of the object cacheCanvas.
     * If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'
     * @type fabric.Object
     */
name: clipPath
description:
a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center
of the object cacheCanvas.
If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'

comment:
/**
     * Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
     * if true, the clipPath will make the object clip to the outside of the clipPath
     * since 2.4.0
     * @type boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: inverted
description:
Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will make the object clip to the outside of the clipPath
since 2.4.0

comment:
/**
     * Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
     * if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
     * not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
     * to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
     * WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
     * since 2.4.0
     * @type boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: absolutePositioned
description:
Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
since 2.4.0

/**
     * Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
     * and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
     * those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
     * making bargain with performances.
     * @param {Object} dims
     * @param {Object} dims.width width of canvas
     * @param {Object} dims.height height of canvas
     * @param {Object} dims.zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @param {Object} dims.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @return {Object}.width width of canvas
     * @return {Object}.height height of canvas
     * @return {Object}.zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @return {Object}.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     */
name: _limitCacheSize
description:
Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
making bargain with performances.

returns.description: .zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache

params.description: zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a fill
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the fill is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasFill
description:
return true if the object will draw a fill
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the fill is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

name: willDrawShadow
description:
Check if this object or a child object will cast a shadow
used by Group.shouldCache to know if child has a shadow recursively

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
params.name: options

params.description: Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.left

params.description: Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.top

params.description: Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
params.name: options.enableRetinaScaling

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
params.name: options.withoutShadow

     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time

     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.

return true if the object will draw a stroke

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

used by Group.shouldCache to know if child has a shadow recursively

/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
params.name: options

params.description: Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.left

params.description: Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.top

params.description: Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
params.name: options.enableRetinaScaling

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
params.name: options.withoutShadow

/**

     * if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
     * not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
     * to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
     * WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
     * since 2.4.0
     * @type boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: absolutePositioned
description:
Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
since 2.4.0

Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
params.name: options

params.description: Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.left

params.description: Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.top

params.description: Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
params.name: options.enableRetinaScaling

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
params.name: options.withoutShadow

Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.

     * @return {Object}.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache

Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
making bargain with performances.

     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

     * some use case where the fill is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

/**
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     */
name: _renderStroke

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drawbacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     * @return {CanvasPattern} a pattern to use as fill/stroke style
     */
name: _applyPatternGradientTransformText
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drawbacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

returns.description: a pattern to use as fill/stroke style

When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular

     * When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled

     * default to true
     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default true
     */
name: noScaleCache
description:
When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
this setting is performance and application dependant.

a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center

If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'

Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

used by Group.shouldCache to know if child has a shadow recursively

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2

Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a fill
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the fill is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasFill
description:
return true if the object will draw a fill
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the fill is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

name: willDrawShadow

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
params.name: options

params.description: Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.left

params.description: Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.top

params.description: Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
params.name: options.enableRetinaScaling

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
params.name: options.withoutShadow

When set to `false`, an object can not be selected for modification (using either point-click-based or group-based selection).
But events still fire on it.

/**
     * When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular

     * or if your application does not allow you to modify properties for groups child you want
     * to disable it for groups.
     * default to false
     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: statefullCache
description:
When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular
situation you may want this to be disabled ( spray brush, very big, groups)
or if your application does not allow you to modify properties for groups child you want
to disable it for groups.
default to false
since 1.7.0

comment:
/**
     * When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
     * too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
     * this setting is performance and application dependant.
     * default to true
     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default true
     */
name: noScaleCache
description:
When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
this setting is performance and application dependant.
default to true
since 1.7.0

a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center

If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'

Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will make the object clip to the outside of the clipPath

/**
     * Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
     * if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
     * not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
     * to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
     * WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
     * since 2.4.0
     * @type boolean
     * @default false
     */

description:
Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.

/**
     * Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
     * and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
     * those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
     * making bargain with performances.
     * @param {Object} dims
     * @param {Object} dims.width width of canvas
     * @param {Object} dims.height height of canvas
     * @param {Object} dims.zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @param {Object} dims.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @return {Object}.width width of canvas
     * @return {Object}.height height of canvas
     * @return {Object}.zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @return {Object}.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     */
name: _limitCacheSize
description:
Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
making bargain with performances.

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

     * some use case where the fill is invisible.

return true if the object will draw a fill
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time

/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

description:
Check if this object or a child object will cast a shadow
used by Group.shouldCache to know if child has a shadow recursively

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
params.name: callback

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
params.name: options

params.description: Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.left

params.description: Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
params.name: options.top

params.description: Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
params.name: options.enableRetinaScaling

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
params.name: options.withoutTransform

params.description: Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
params.name: options.withoutShadow

comment:
/**
     * Converts an object into a HTMLCanvas element
     * @param {Object} options Options object
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14

When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular
situation you may want this to be disabled ( spray brush, very big, groups)

to disable it for groups.
default to false

     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default true
     */

description:
When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled

this setting is performance and application dependant.
