name: clipPath
description:
a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center
of the object cacheCanvas.
If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke

     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.

     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.

return true if the object will draw a stroke

     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4

     * @return {Object} object.width distance between X coordinates of the polygon leftmost and rightmost point
     * @return {Object} object.height distance between Y coordinates of the polygon topmost and bottommost point
     * @private
     */
name: _calcDimensions
description:
Calculate the polygon min and max point from points array,
returning an object with left, top, width, height to measure the
polygon size

returns.description: object.left X coordinate of the polygon leftmost point
object.top Y coordinate of the polygon topmost point
object.width distance between X coordinates of the polygon leftmost and rightmost point
object.height distance between Y coordinates of the polygon topmost and bottommost point

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasStroke
description:
return true if the object will draw a stroke
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
some use case where the stroke is invisible.

comment:
/**
     * return true if the object will draw a fill
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.

     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the fill is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: hasFill
description:
return true if the object will draw a fill
Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when fill happens,
can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses

comment:
/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4

return true if the object will draw a stroke

/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drawbacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     * @return {CanvasPattern} a pattern to use as fill/stroke style
     */
name: _applyPatternGradientTransformText
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drawbacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

returns.description: a pattern to use as fill/stroke style

When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular
situation you may want this to be disabled ( spray brush, very big, groups)

comment:
/**
     * When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled

     * @type Boolean
     * @default true
     */

description:
When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
this setting is performance and application dependant.

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */

return true if the object will draw a stroke

     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden

     * @returns Boolean
     */

it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument

     * to disable it for groups.
     * default to false

     * @type Boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: statefullCache
description:
When `true`, object properties are checked for cache invalidation. In some particular
situation you may want this to be disabled ( spray brush, very big, groups)
or if your application does not allow you to modify properties for groups child you want
to disable it for groups.
default to false
since 1.7.0

comment:
/**
     * When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
     * too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
     * this setting is performance and application dependant.
     * default to true
     * since 1.7.0
     * @type Boolean
     * @default true
     */
name: noScaleCache
description:
When `true`, cache does not get updated during scaling. The picture will get blocky if scaled
too much and will be redrawn with correct details at the end of scaling.
this setting is performance and application dependant.
default to true
since 1.7.0

     * a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
     * the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center
     * of the object cacheCanvas.
     * If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'
     * @type fabric.Object
     */
name: clipPath
description:
a fabricObject that, without stroke define a clipping area with their shape. filled in black
the clipPath object gets used when the object has rendered, and the context is placed in the center
of the object cacheCanvas.
If you want 0,0 of a clipPath to align with an object center, use clipPath.originX/Y to 'center'

comment:
/**
     * Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
     * if true, the clipPath will make the object clip to the outside of the clipPath
     * since 2.4.0
     * @type boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: inverted
description:
Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will make the object clip to the outside of the clipPath
since 2.4.0

comment:
/**
     * Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
     * if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
     * not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
     * to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
     * WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
     * since 2.4.0
     * @type boolean
     * @default false
     */
name: absolutePositioned
description:
Meaningful ONLY when the object is used as clipPath.
if true, the clipPath will have its top and left relative to canvas, and will
not be influenced by the object transform. This will make the clipPath relative
to the canvas, but clipping just a particular object.
WARNING this is beta, this feature may change or be renamed.
since 2.4.0

/**
     * Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
     * and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
     * those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
     * making bargain with performances.
     * @param {Object} dims
     * @param {Object} dims.width width of canvas
     * @param {Object} dims.height height of canvas
     * @param {Object} dims.zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @param {Object} dims.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @return {Object}.width width of canvas
     * @return {Object}.height height of canvas
     * @return {Object}.zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     * @return {Object}.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
     */
name: _limitCacheSize
description:
Limit the cache dimensions so that X * Y do not cross fabric.perfLimitSizeTotal
and each side do not cross fabric.cacheSideLimit
those numbers are configurable so that you can get as much detail as you want
making bargain with performances.

returns.description: .zoomX zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
.zoomY zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache

params.description: zoomX zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
params.name: dims.zoomX

params.description: zoomY zoom value to unscale the canvas before drawing cache
params.name: dims.zoomY

     * @return {Object}.height height of canvas

/**
     * return true if the object will draw a stroke
     * Does not consider text styles. This is just a shortcut used at rendering time
     * We want it to be an approximation and be fast.
     * wrote to avoid extra caching, it has to return true when stroke happens,
     * can guess when it will not happen at 100% chance, does not matter if it misses
     * some use case where the stroke is invisible.
     * @since 3.0.0
     * @returns Boolean
     */

return true if the object will draw a stroke

/**
     * When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
     * it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
     * its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
     * Created to be overridden
     * since 1.7.12
     * @returns Boolean
     */
name: needsItsOwnCache
description:
When set to `true`, force the object to have its own cache, even if it is inside a group
it may be needed when your object behave in a particular way on the cache and always needs
its own isolated canvas to render correctly.
Created to be overridden
since 1.7.12

comment:
/**
     * Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
     * objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
     * needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
     * a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
     * Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
     * Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.
     * @return {Boolean}
     */
name: shouldCache
description:
Decide if the object should cache or not. Create its own cache level
objectCaching is a global flag, wins over everything
needsItsOwnCache should be used when the object drawing method requires
a cache step. None of the fabric classes requires it.
Generally you do not cache objects in groups because the group outside is cached.
Read as: cache if is needed, or if the feature is enabled but we are not already caching.

used by Group.shouldCache to know if child has a shadow recursively

comment:
/**
     * This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
     * transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
     * we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
     * a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
     * this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
     * is limited.
     * @private
     * @param {CanvasRenderingContext2D} ctx Context to render on
     * @param {fabric.Gradient} filler a fabric gradient instance
     */
name: _applyPatternForTransformedGradient
description:
This function try to patch the missing gradientTransform on canvas gradients.
transforming a context to transform the gradient, is going to transform the stroke too.
we want to transform the gradient but not the stroke operation, so we create
a transformed gradient on a pattern and then we use the pattern instead of the gradient.
this method has drwabacks: is slow, is in low resolution, needs a patch for when the size
is limited.

comment:
/**
     * Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
     * makes use of toCanvasElement.
     * Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
     * and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
     * If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
     * toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
     * This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
     * When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.
     * @param {Function} callback callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument
     * @param {Object} [options] for clone as image, passed to toDataURL
     * @param {Number} [options.multiplier=1] Multiplier to scale by
     * @param {Number} [options.left] Cropping left offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.top] Cropping top offset. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.width] Cropping width. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Number} [options.height] Cropping height. Introduced in v1.2.14
     * @param {Boolean} [options.enableRetinaScaling] Enable retina scaling for clone image. Introduce in 1.6.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutTransform] Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
     * @param {Boolean} [options.withoutShadow] Remove current object shadow. Introduced in 2.4.2
     * @return {fabric.Object} thisArg
     */
name: cloneAsImage
description:
Creates an instance of fabric.Image out of an object
makes use of toCanvasElement.
Once this method was based on toDataUrl and loadImage, so it also had a quality
and format option. toCanvasElement is faster and produce no loss of quality.
If you need to get a real Jpeg or Png from an object, using toDataURL is the right way to do it.
toCanvasElement and then toBlob from the obtained canvas is also a good option.
This method is sync now, but still support the callback because we did not want to break.
When fabricJS 5.0 will be planned, this will probably be changed to not have a callback.

params.description: callback, invoked with an instance as a first argument

params.description: for clone as image, passed to toDataURL

params.description: Remove current object transform ( no scale , no angle, no flip, no skew ). Introduced in 2.3.4
